title: Death Analysis of New York State
text:
1 Introduction
New York State, with its diverse and populous nature, is a microcosm of the broader United States. The patterns and trends observed in New York can provide valuable insights into the larger national picture. Suicide, alcohol-related deaths, and firearm fatalities are major contributors to mortality and have profound impacts on public health, families, and communities. Understanding their dynamics in New York can inform public health strategies both within the state and beyond.
Exploring the topic of suicide and alcohol-related deaths through data analysis presents a compelling and socially significant avenue of study, one that holds immense potential for impacting public health policies, mental health awareness, and societal wellbeing at large. Suicide, as a public health crisis, carries a profound and often understated impact on communities worldwide, cutting across age, gender, race, and socio-economic boundaries. Delving into this topic is not just about understanding statistics; it’s about uncovering the hidden narratives behind these numbers, narratives that can guide interventions, shape public discourse, and lead to life-saving changes in how societies address mental health.
There are several questions we are interested in exploring with further data analysis and visualization: How do suicide rates vary across different age groups, genders, and ethnicities in New York State? Has there been a significant change in the rate of suicide or alcohol-related deaths in New York State over the years? Which regions in New York State have the highest rates of suicide, alcohol-related, and firearm deaths? These questions can guide us through the following analysis of the dataset, helping to uncover critical insights and inform targeted interventions for improving public health outcomes in New York State.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.1 Description
The dataset titled “Vital Statistics Suicide Deaths by Age-Group, Race/Ethnicity, Resident Region, and Gender, Beginning 2003” is an invaluable resource provided by the New York State Department of Health and is accessible through New York State’s Open Data platform at health.data.ny.gov. This comprehensive dataset, with 4297 rows and 8 columns, is compiled primarily from death certificates, encompassing detailed information categorized by year, region, race or ethnicity, sex, age group, and the incidence of firearm and alcohol-related deaths, alongside suicide deaths. It is offered in several formats, including CSV, RDF, and XML. This variety ensures compatibility with a range of data analysis tools and software environments, allowing for flexibility in how the data is processed and analyzed. Importing this dataset begins with downloading the CSV file of the dataset from the New York State’s Open Data platform. Once downloaded, the dataset can be read into R using the ‘read.csv’ function. Post-import, we perform initial inspections using functions like ‘head()’ to understand the structure and to identify any immediate issues. This step is followed by data cleaning and preprocessing, which might include handling missing values, correcting data types, or renaming columns for clarity.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.2 Research plan
For the exploration of suicide rates across different demographics: the dataset categorizes suicide deaths by age groups. This allows for an analysis of how suicide rates differ among various age brackets, enabling us to identify which age groups are most at risk. With data broken down by gender, we can compare suicide rates between males and females, uncovering any gender-specific trends or disparities in suicide occurrences. Moreover, the inclusion of race or ethnicity in the data provides an opportunity to explore how suicide rates vary among different racial and ethnic groups within New York State. This can reveal critical insights into the socio-cultural aspects that might influence these rates.
For the changes in suicide and alcohol-related deaths over time: the dataset spans multiple years, providing a temporal dimension that is key to analyzing trends over time. We can investigate whether the rates of suicide or alcohol-related deaths have increased, decreased, or remained stable across different periods. This longitudinal analysis is crucial for identifying emerging trends or the impact of public health initiatives and socio-economic changes over the years.
For the geographical distribution of suicide, alcohol-related, and firearm deaths: since the data is categorized by region, it allows for a geographical analysis of suicide, alcohol-related, and firearm deaths. We can identify which regions in New York State have higher or lower rates of these incidents. By comparing different regions within the state, we can uncover patterns that might be linked to regional characteristics, such as socio-economic factors or availability/accessibility to mental health resources.

title: 2  Data
text:
2.3 Missing value analysis
Two different types of missing values have been identified in two columns respectively. There are 833 ‘Not Stated’ values in the ‘Race or Ethnicity’ column and 13 ‘Unknown’ values in the ‘Age Group’ column. Since there are 833 rows with ‘Not Stated’ out of 4297 total rows, we decided to keep the ‘Not Stated’ values as a new category along with other races. Since there are only 13 rows with ‘Unknown’ out of 4297 total rows, we decided to remove these rows from our dataset.

library(RColorBrewer)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

Code
library(ggrepel)
death_data <- read.csv("Death_data_NY.csv")


race_counts <- as.data.frame(table(death_data$Race.or.Ethnicity))

ggplot(race_counts, aes(x="", y=Freq, fill=Var1)) +
  geom_bar(stat="identity", width=1) +
  coord_polar("y", start=0) +
  theme_minimal() +  
  theme(axis.line = element_blank(),
        axis.text = element_blank(),
        axis.title = element_blank(),
        panel.border = element_blank(),
        panel.grid = element_blank(),
        axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        plot.title = element_text(size=22)) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette="Pastel1") +  
  labs(fill="Race or Ethnicity", title="Pie Chart of Race or Ethnicity") +
  guides(fill=guide_legend(title="Race or Ethnicity"))





Code
death_data$Color <- ifelse(death_data$Age.Group == "Unknown", "Unknown", "Other")
ggplot(death_data, aes(x=Age.Group, fill=Color)) +
  geom_bar() +
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("Unknown"="steelblue", "Other"="lightblue")) +
  labs(title="Bar Chart of Age Groups", x="Age Group", y="Count") +
  theme_minimal() +  # Using a minimal theme for a clean look
  guides(fill=FALSE) # Using a minimal theme for a clean look
